Zilina is the fourth largest town in Slovakia.

Recently there was a large investment from Kia Motors Company in Zilina. By mid 2007, Kia expect to be producing 300 000 units per year! A large automobile factory is being build in a nearby area and a lot of Kia employees from Korea have moved to Zilina. Because of this, you can find specialized Korean food sections in some larger supermarkets and some Korean restaurants.

. Trains can be caught from Bratislava main train station (

(available in English also) for train and bus connections in Slovakia and countries around.

as highway D1. Road E442 from
airport on the number 61 bus (price €0.75) to Bratislava main train station (
). After that by train to Zilina.
The centre is small enough to walk around. There is also public city transport, around 50 cents ticket.
Take a stroll in the historic centre and admire the old churches.

- get local cheese from cheese shops, much better and fresher than from supermarkets. E.g. Syrmix on Narodna street or Kuzmanyho Street, shops close to market
- during season good source of vegetable and fruits, sometime you can find here locals with only their things (not from big stores). Over corner of Kuzmanyho and Halkova street.
- smoked sheep cheese, similar to Polish
- pasta dumplings with bryndza (soft sheep cheese)

Every restaurant has non-smoking part (by law).
During lunch most of restaurants serve 'menu' for about €3-4 (including soup).

content=Pork or chicken escalopes (wiener schnitzel), chicken and pasta dish, a meat and rice dish, served with potatoes and vegetable and a drink, all for a very reasonable 4 €. Pleasant little place.

There are many pubs, restaurants and tearooms around town. Beer is especially cheap at just over €1 per half litre. 

There are a few pubs and bars on the main square. There is an Irish bar, aptly named 'Guinness' and also a disco style bar called Royales. 

Typical Slovak (and Czech) soft drink is
. Kind of coke drink, not so sweet.

value: content=Very comfortable. Big choice of teas, ice creams. They have books to read, board games to play.

content=Is a good cheap option although quite far from the train and bus stations. Private rooms with sinks for €10-€15 a night, on the 9th and 10th floors. No internet but nearby restaurant has free wifi.

, Hlinkovo namesti square, +421 (0)41 723 31 86, till end of June: Monday-Friday 8-17, Saturday 9-12, Sunday closed, in high season Monday-Friday 8-18, Saturday-Sunday 9-14.
on their website: practical contacts, tips for tips, prospects to download, list of cultural events, ...
including photos of hotels, shops, parks, hills, quarters, transport, schools, churches, industries, health centers.

Like any central European town, be practical. The railway station is not the greatest place to "have" to stop over in for any length of time based on experience. Suggest avoid waiting room, and stay near kiosks. Otherwise, Zilina is fine. Enjoy!
There are many great places close to Zilina.

value: - part of Zilina, just over the river Vah. Lovely park, castle currently closed. Walk there.
- on hill in the middle of forest with great view to river meander. Do a day trip: by train to Strecno, go to Strecno castle, cross river and go up to Starhrad and back.
- big castle just next road to Liptovský Mikuláš, paid entrance, open Mo-Su  9.00 - 18.00 (last Entrance 17.15). By train or bus to Strecno village.
